- *For the monster class, see [Troll (monster class)](/wiki/Troll_\(monster_class\) "Troll (monster class)").*

A **troll**, T, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is the most basic type of [troll](/wiki/Troll_\(monster_class\) "Troll (monster class)") and generally the first that [you](/wiki/You "You") will encounter. A troll has enhanced [regeneration](/wiki/Regeneration "Regeneration") and will [follow](/wiki/Follow "Follow") you to other levels if adjacent, and can often [revive](/wiki/Revive "Revive") from its corpse when killed.

A troll has a weapon attack, a claw attack, and a bite attack.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [5.2 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [5.3 TNNT (the game)](#TNNT_.28the_game.29)

- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly generated trolls are always generated hostile.

Trolls may appear among the hostile T that generate in [throne rooms](/wiki/Throne_room "Throne room"), as well the monsters randomly generated by [looting](/wiki/Looting "Looting") a throne while [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused") and carrying gold (provided there is no [chest](/wiki/Chest "Chest") on the level).[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

Trolls are the second [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") monster for [Barbarians](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian"), and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters that randomly generate on the [Barbarian quest](/wiki/Barbarian_quest "Barbarian quest") - they can also generate among the random T that are part of the second quest [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class") and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters that are randomly generated there.

The [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") may create a clone of himself in the guise of a troll via the [Double Trouble](/wiki/Double_Trouble "Double Trouble") [monster spell](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell").[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

Trolls have a 1⁄2 chance of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a [ranseur](/wiki/Ranseur "Ranseur"), [partisan](/wiki/Partisan "Partisan"), [glaive](/wiki/Glaive "Glaive"), or [spetum](/wiki/Spetum "Spetum"), with an equal probability of each polearm.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

## Strategy

Trolls hit hard, move as fast as an unhasted unburdened player, and will often need to be fought multiple times before they are fully defeated. However, they have no elemental [resistances](/wiki/Resistance "Resistance") or [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)") to speak of, making them vulnerable to many type of magical attacks including [sleep](/wiki/Sleep "Sleep") or [slowing](/wiki/Slowing "Slowing").

While a player may be capable of fighting a troll once or twice, repeated fights can whittle down your HP over time if the troll revives quickly enough, and it is risky to rely on a troll simply failing to revive eventually. To get rid of them permanently, you can [eat](/wiki/Eat "Eat") them (though they may still revive as you are doing so), throw them into [water](/wiki/Pool "Pool") or [lava](/wiki/Lava "Lava"), or turn them to [stone](/wiki/Stoning "Stoning"). You can also lure them to the [Rogue level](/wiki/Rogue_level "Rogue level"), where corpses do not drop, as they can follow you up or down stairs. A meat-eating [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") or a [tinning kit](/wiki/Tinning_kit "Tinning kit") will reliably dispose of a troll corpse, and you can also lug the corpse to a nearby [container](/wiki/Container "Container") that you can lock it in.

## History

The troll first appears in Hack 1.21 and Hack for PDP-11, both based on [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"), and is included in the initial bestiary for [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Troll](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troll "wikipedia:Troll")***

A troll is a being that appears in Norse mythology and later Scandinavian folklore. In Old Norse sources, beings described as trolls dwell in isolated areas of rock, mountains, or caves, living together in small family units, and were rarely helpful to human beings - the Old Norse nouns *troll* and *trǫll* are variously used to mean "fiend", "demon", "werewolf", and "jötunn". The trolls of *NetHack* are derived from *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, whose portrayal of them is partly inspired by [Poul Anderson](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poul_Anderson "wikipedia:Poul Anderson") novel *[Three Hearts and Three Lions](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Hearts_and_Three_Lions "wikipedia:Three Hearts and Three Lions")*.

*D\&D* trolls are typically nine feet tall on average, with rubbery green or gray hide, gaunt and deceptively-thin builds, and long arms that drag across the ground and dangle when running. A troll's hunched posture and uneven gait masks great physical strength and agility: they are fearless fighters that attack relentlessly with their claws and teeth, rarely using weapons, and have the ability to rapidly heal wounds and even animate disembodied parts of themselves, as well as a weakness to fire. Trolls hunt most other living creatures for prey and have no natural predators, though they respect groups that are known to wield fire - both fire and acid were the only ways of counteracting a troll's regenerative abilities.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), trolls [hit as a +1 weapon](/wiki/Hits_creatures_as_%2Bx_weapon "Hits creatures as +x weapon"), and tame trolls may turn [traitor](/wiki/Traitor "Traitor").

[Grund's Stronghold](/wiki/Grund%27s_Stronghold "Grund's Stronghold") has a 4⁄5 chance of generating a troll at level creation.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), two trolls are generated in the forested area on the Ancient Temple level of the [Chaos Temple Quest](/wiki/Chaos_Temple_Quest "Chaos Temple Quest") at level creation.

Trolls may appear in the court of a [throne room](/wiki/Throne_room#dNetHack "Throne room") ruled by an [ogre king](/wiki/Ogre_king "Ogre king").

### TNNT (the game)

In [TNNT (the game)](/wiki/TNNT_\(the_game\) "TNNT (the game)"), [the DevTeam Office](/wiki/The_DevTeam_Office "The DevTeam Office") has a 1⁄5 chance of generating a peaceful troll named MR SHOUTY at level creation.

## Encyclopedia entry

The troll shambled closer. He was perhaps eight feet tall,  
perhaps more. His forward stoop, with arms dangling past  
thick claw-footed legs to the ground, made it hard to tell.  
The hairless green skin moved upon his body. His head was a  
gash of a mouth, a yard-long nose, and two eyes which drank  
the feeble torchlight and never gave back a gleam.  
\[...]  
Like a huge green spider, the troll's severed hand ran on its  
fingers. Across the mounded floor, up onto a log with one  
taloned forefinger to hook it over the bark, down again it  
 scrambled, until it found the cut wrist. And there it grew  
fast. The troll's smashed head seethed and knit together.  
He clambered back on his feet and grinned at them. The  
waning faggot cast red light over his fangs.

\[ Three Hearts and Three Lions, by Poul Anderson ]
